Ok, I'm a little confused.
I've been using JUnit for a while and using single decorators to 
create the environment for all the tests to run it.
I have now started writing some new tests where I want to run the 
same tests in a variety of different environments.  I thought I could 
just have a number of Decorators and add them to the suite so that in 
turn the tests are run instead each decorator.  Example of suite.

    public static Test suite()
    {
        TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Some Tests");

        suite.addTest(new TestSetupA(new TestSuite(MyTests.class)));
        suite.addTest(new TestSetupB(new TestSuite(MyTests.class)));
        
        .
        .
        .

        suite.addTest(new TestSetupX(new TestSuite(MyTests.class)));

        return suite;
    }

So in this case I use TestSetupA to create an environment that all 
the test cases in MyTests are run inside.  I then create a new 
environment using TestSetupB for the same test cases etc.

The problem I am having is that for every TestSetup decorator I add 
it makes the tests run that many times.  If I have 3 decorators then 
TestSetupA.setUp() is run 3 times. Then all the test cases are run 3 
times, then TestSetupA.tearDown() 3 times.  After that 
TestSetupB.setUp() is called 3 times, then all tests are run 3 times 
and TestSetupB.tearDown() 3 times, etc.

Why is this happening, is it a bug or is there another was I should 
solve this solution of running the test cases in different 
environments?

Thanks for any information (esp. if you understand me :)

 Tony
